In an interview, Mubarak said that he was "fed up" with being in power but would not resign because he did not want Egypt to descend into a chaos in which the Muslim Brotherhood would be the beneficiaries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12361948 |title=Mubarak 'Fears Chaos If He Quits' |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 3 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Suleiman said, in the same interview, that the Egyptian people do not have a culture of democracy and that an Islamic current is pushing young people to protest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/watch/this-week/SH559082/VD55110136/this-week-206-what-happens-next-in-egypt|title=What Happens Next in Egypt?|date= 6 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> In an interview broadcast on state television, Suleiman reasserted that "The president will not go for another term nor any member of his family including his son. The January 25 youth was not a destructive movement, however it was a demand movement...Constitution articles 76 and 77 will be modified, other articles are subjected to change." Regarding the clashes in Tahrir Square he commented, "Everyone responsible for these clashes will be questioned...The clashes had negatively impacted what the president speech had achieved." About economic effects he commented, "A million tourists had left Egypt in 9 days, imagine the lost revenue." He declared that anyone who had been arrested during the demonstrations would be released unless they had committed a crime. He asked the protesters to go home as all their demands had been heard. He thanked them for their efforts to move political life in Egypt forward.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/03/136077.html |title=Ù ÙØ¹ Ø£Ø­Ù Ø¯ Ø¹Ø² Ù3 ÙØ²Ø±Ø§Ø¡ Ù ØµØ±ÙÙÙ Ø³Ø§Ø¨ÙÙÙ Ù Ù Ø§ÙØ³ÙØ± ÙØ¨Ø¯Ø¡ Ø§ÙØªØ­ÙÙÙ Ù Ø¹ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ø¯ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|publisher=Alarabiya.net|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
Bloomberg reported that Vodafone had been forced by the Egyptian government to send SMS text messages to its customers. The pro-Mubarak messages characterized protesters as disloyal and called upon recipients to "confront" them. Vodafone CEO [[Vittorio Colao]] reported that the general public was still blocked from sending text messages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/vodafone-ordered-to-send-egyptian-government-messages-update1-.html |title=Vodafone Says It Was Instructed to Send Pro-Mubarak Messages to Customers |publisher=bloomberg.com|accessdate=2011-02-03}}</ref>
===4 February â Friday of Departure=== [[File:Tahrir Square during Friday of Departure.png|thumb|Tahrir Square during the "Friday of Departure"]] [[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|A tank at the entrance to Tahrir Square]] The organizers of the "Day of Revolt" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬Ù Ø¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬Ù Ø¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February as their deadline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as many of the protesters again spent the night in Tahrir Square. Pro-government protesters were active and small-scale clashes happened in the early hours.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/03/live-blog-feb-4-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 4 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
Two million Egyptians flooded Tahrir Square to participate in Friday prayer in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=235172|title=2 million Egyptians turn out for Day of Departure|publisher=[[Tehran Times]]|date=2011-02-05|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> [[Egyptian Christians]] and others not performing Friday prayers formed a "human chain" around those praying to protect them from potential disruptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/02/the-day-of-departure-its-either-death-or-freedom.html|author=Chris Bodenner|title="The Day Of Departure": Calm But Determined|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=}}</ref> The day's planned events began after prayers. Al Jazeera estimated the crowd size to be over one million in Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://www.demotix.com/news/579902/flags-egypt-raised-above-tahrir-square "Flags of Egypt raised above Tahrir Square"] ''Demotix - News By You'' - Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref> Protesters held portraits of former presidents [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] and [[Anwar Sadat]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/05/stories/2011020565420100.htm |title=Front Page : Ball in Mubarak's court as democracy pressure mounts |publisher=The Hindu |date= 5 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-05 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref> However, protesters did not get to the presidential palace. In Alexandria, over a million protesters turned out, making it the biggest-ever protest there. They warned that if the government used violence against protesters in Cairo, they would march to Cairo to join the protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb" />
Protest marches were also held in Giza and [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201124175331299951.html |title=Egypt holds 'Day of Departure' - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Suez, [[Port Said]], [[Rafah, Egypt|Rafah]], [[IsmaÃ¯lia|Ismailiya]], [[Zagazig]], [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|al-Mahalla al-Kubra]], [[Aswan]] and [[Asyut]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12371479 Obama seeks quick Egypt handover], BBC News, 5 Feb 2011</ref>
The Prosecutor General followed up travel bans and frozen bank accounts on former ministers and government officials including former Minister of Trade and Industry [[Rachid Mohamed Rachid]]. He told ''Al Arabiya'' that "I returned from Davos to Egypt because of the current situation in Egypt. The new Prime Minister had contacted me for the same position in the new cabinet, I refused because I want fresh blood." Regarding the travel ban, he commented, "I had no idea about the accusations, I served for six and half years and I am completely ready to face any accusation. No one had informed me of this decision and I heard it from the news." He was considered a possible candidate for Prime Minister before the protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/04/136258.html |title=Ø§ÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø¨ Ø§ÙØ¹Ø§Ù ÙØµØ¯Ø± ÙØ±Ø§Ø±Ø§Ù Ø¨Ù ÙØ¹ ÙØ²ÙØ± Ø§ÙØªØ¬Ø§Ø±Ø© Ø§ÙØ³Ø§Ø¨Ù Ù Ù Ø§ÙØ³ÙØ± ÙØªØ¬Ù ÙØ¯ Ø­Ø³Ø§Ø¨Ø§ØªÙ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date=4 February 2011}}</ref>
''The New York Times'' and ''Bloomberg'' reported that the US administration is in talks with Egyptian officials over a proposal for Mubarak to resign immediately, turning over power to a transitional government headed by the Vice-President,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/04/world/middleeast/04diplomacy.html?_r=1&ref=global-home |title=White House and Egypt Discuss Plan for Mubarakâs Exit |publisher=Nytimes.com |date= 3 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-05 |first1=Helene |last1=Cooper |first2=Mark |last2=Landler}}</ref> because the longer Mubarak held on to power the more "strident" protesters would become.<ref>{{cite web|last=Dorning |first=Mike |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/u-s-increases-pressure-on-egypt-military-to-accelerate-mubarak-departure.html |title=U.S. Increases Pressure to Speed Up Mubarak Departure |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
Ahmad Mohamed Mahmoud of ''Al-Ta'awun'' became the first journalist to die covering the protests,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cpj.org/2011/02/press-attacks-cairo-reporter-dies.php |title=(Committee to Protect Journalists) |publisher=Cpj.org |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> from gunshot wounds sustained on 28 January.<ref>{{cite news|author=|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/white-house-press-secretary-robert-gibbs-said-friday-that-the-obamas-administration-continues-to-receive-very-disturbing-repo.html |title=EGYPT: Reporter who was shot last week dies at local hospital | Babylon & Beyond | Los Angeles Times |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
===5 February=== [[File:'You shall rise' Egyptian Revolution.png|thumb|left|An Egyptian protester holding the Egyptian flag with one hand while showing the [[V sign]] with the other]] [[File:Broadcast of the revolution.jpg|thumb|The so-called ''Etha'et al-thawra'' (broadcast of the revolution), set upon an elevated stage and used by the demonstrators in Tahrir Square to address the crowds. In the background is the [[American University in Cairo]].]]
During the night of 4â5 February, a few protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square, though it was largely quiet. Early in the morning shots were fired as protesters said pro-Mubarak activists tried to assault the square. Troops then fired into the air to disperse them. Demonstrators later formed a human chain to prevent tanks from passing through the barricades into the square; a witness said scuffles broke out when an army general asked demonstrators to take down their make-shift barricades of corrugated steel and debris.<ref name="CNN 5 Feb">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/05/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1|title=Egypt's government meets opposition as protests continue|newspaper=[[CNN]]|author=CNN Wire Staff|date=February 5, 2011|accessdate=February 5, 2011}}</ref> As the army tightened access to Tahrir Square, the head of the army met protesters<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/05/us-egypt-protests-idUSTRE7141S820110205 |title=Egypt army seeks to free Tahrir Square for traffic |publisher= |date= 5 February 2011|accessdate=2011-04-08 |work=Reuters}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> and asked them to return home. Protesters responded that "he (Mubarak) will go" and they would not. The army was also more organized and present than on any other day of the protest.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/04/live-blog-feb-5-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 5 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> A heavy military presence continued in central Cairo. An Interior Ministry spokesman said that "the army remains neutral and is not taking sides because if we protect one side we will be perceived as biased....our role is to prevent clashes and chaos as we separate the opposing groups."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" /> Scuffles were reported during the day in Tahrir Square and one protester was said to have died. A group of foreigners including an English protester on the 5th and a Swede on the 6th<ref>{{cite web|url=http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Swedish_protester_in_Tahrir.jpg |title=File:Swedish protester in Tahrir.jpg - Wikimedia Commons |publisher=Commons.wikimedia.org |date=2011-02-06 |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> joined the protesters in Tahrir Square, handing out flowers in a sign of solidarity and holding up a banner in English. Five hundred protesters arrived in Tahrir Square from Suez. There were reports of over 10,000 people continuing to stay in Alexandria through the night.<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" />
State television announced the appointment of [[Hossam Badrawi]] ''(seen as a member of the liberal wing of the party)''<ref name="aljazbloglive5feb" /> as Head of the Shura Council after [[Safwat El-Sherif]]'s resignation from his position within the party. Mubarak's son [[Gamal Mubarak|Gamal]] also resigned as Assistant Secretary and Secretary of the Policy Committee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alarabiya.net/articles/2011/02/05/136363.html |title=Ø¥ÙØµØ§Ø¡ Ø¬Ù Ø§Ù ÙØ§ÙØ´Ø±ÙÙ Ù Ù Ø§ÙØ­Ø²Ø¨ Ø§ÙÙØ·ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙ ØµØ±Ù.. ÙØªØ¹ÙÙÙ Ø¨Ø¯Ø±Ø§ÙÙ Ø£Ù ÙÙØ§ |publisher=Alarabiya.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Minister of State for Legal Affairs Mufid Shehab and Presidential Chief-of-Staff [[Zakaria Azmy]] were dismissed from the party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/310041 |title=NDP overhaul a meager concession, says opposition | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Initial reports indicated that Mubarak had resigned as head of the ruling NDP party,<ref>{{cite web|author=Mike Dowling |url=http://www.thejournal.ie/mubarak-focuses-on-economic-issues-as-protests-continue-2011-02/ |title=Protests continue in Egypt as NDP leadership resigns Â· TheJournal |publisher=Thejournal.ie |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> however this was later denied by state television and the Information Minister.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hossam Badrawi replaces NDP's Secretary general Safwat El Sherif and Gamal Mubarak|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/News/5039.aspx|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Ahram Online|date=5 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Information Minister denies Mubarak's resignation from ruling party|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/311088|accessdate=6 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=6 February 2011}}</ref> Former Interior Minister Habib el-Adli and three of his leadership were put under house arrest. There had been reports about the arrest of other security leaders who were being held in a military prison.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/308543|title=Egyptâs attorney-general bans former ministers and officials from travel|publisher=Almasry Alyoum|date= |accessdate=2011-02-07}}</ref> However, the opposition leaders continued to seek ways to remove Mubarak from power. They called on the protesters to continue at Tahrir Square every Tuesday and Friday until Mubarak "resigns and makes true the demands of the people."<ref name="CNN 5 Feb" />
Trouble hit the border city of [[Rafah|Rafa]] as a grenade was tossed into an empty church and the public library was set on fire on February 5.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/story_print.html?id=4231180&sponsor=|title=Militants blow up Egypt gas pipeline|publisher=[[Vancouver Sun]]|date=2011-02-08|accessdate=2011-02-15}}</ref>
===6 February â Sunday of Martyrs=== {{multiple image | width1 = 230 | width2 = 160 | align = | footer = From left to right: Copts leading the crowd in prayer in Tahrir Square and ''Muslims and Christians United for Egypt'', by [[Carlos Latuff]]. | image1 = Copts praying in Tahrir.jpg | image2 = Muslims and Christians united for Egypt.png }}
The organizers of the "Day of Revolt", "Friday of Anger", "March of the Millions" and "Friday of Departure" called for a protest in what was dubbed the "'''Sunday of Martyrs'''"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5046/Egypt/Politics-/Protesters-plan-Coptic-mass-on-Martyrs-Sunday.aspx|title=Protesters plan Coptic mass on 'Martyrs' Sunday'|publisher=[[Al-Ahram]]|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡}}).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.masrawy.com/News/Egypt/Politics/2011/february/6/pray_quddas.aspx?ref=extraclip|title=ØµÙØ§Ø© ÙÙØºØ§Ø¦Ø¨ ÙØªØ±Ø§ÙÙÙ ÙØ¨Ø·ÙØ© Ø¨Ù ÙØ¯Ø§ÙÙØ¶ÙØ¨ Ø§ÙØªØ­Ø±ÙØ± ÙÙ (Ø£Ø­Ø¯ Ø§ÙØ´ÙØ¯Ø§Ø¡)|publisher=Masrawy|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
During the night of 5â6 February, protesters continued to camp out in Tahrir Square and Alexandria. However, [[gunshot|gunfire]] was heard in the early hours of the day in Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/05/live-blog-feb-6-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 6 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
Egyptian Christians held mass in the morning in Tahrir Square to counter claims by state television that most of the anti-Mubarak protesters were members of the Muslim Brotherhood. Copts wanted to show that they were a part of Egypt's popular uprising and shared the grievances. Christians started their Sunday Mass in Cairo's Tahrir Square as Muslim protesters formed a ring around them to protect them during the service.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.onislam.net/english/news/africa/450890-egypt-christians-muslims-unite-in-tahrir.html|title=Egypt Christians, Muslims Unite in Tahrir|publisher=On Islam|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Crowds in Tahrir Square chanted "We are one, we are one" ahead of prayers held at noon for those killed during the protests.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb" /> Muslims later participated in ''[[Salat al-Janazah]]'' ({{lang-ar|'''ØµÙØ§Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙØ§Ø²Ø©'''}}) (literally: funeral prayer).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=414062&version=1&template_id=37&parent_id=17|title=Prayers, tears for âmartyrsâ|publisher=Gulf Times|accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> Protesters in Cairo numbered in the vicinity of one million.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201126131743308918.html |title=Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt talks - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Demonstrations continued in Alexandria focused around the train station of El Ramel. Several thousand anti-government protesters continued calling for Mubarak's resignation in Mansoura.<ref name="aljazbloglive6feb" /> [[Ayman Mohyeldin]], an ''Al Jazeera English'' journalist, was arrested by soldiers in Tahrir Square, and held for 9 hours.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/02/201127160284430.html |title=Ayman Mohyeldin on his detention |work=Al Jazeera English |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref>
Banks temporarily reopened throughout the country amidst long queues,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/06/us-egypt-banks-idUSTRE7150EZ20110206 |title=Customers queue at Egypt banks after protests |publisher=Reuters |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref> and people rushed to buy US dollars.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/310940 |title=Egypt pound down less than feared, central bank supports |work=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=6 February 2011 |accessdate=6 February 2011}}</ref>
Vice President Suleiman negotiated with the opposition, including {{link-interwiki|en=Mohammed Morsi|lang=ar|lang_title=Ù Ø­Ù Ø¯ Ù Ø±Ø³Ù}} and [[El-Sayyid el-Badawi]]. The Muslim Brotherhood said it was talking with the government.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=BBC News - Egypt unrest |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> Suleiman agreed to set up a committee of judiciary and political figures to study constitutional reforms. The committee was due to meet by early March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110206/D9L7B7IO0.html |title=Egypt's regime makes new concessions to opposition |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref> [[Naguib Sawiris]], who was involved in the talks, said that "big progress" had been made.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hall |first=Camilla |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-07/egyptian-credit-risk-falling-to-lowest-since-protests-started.html |title=Egypt Credit Risk Falls to Lowest Since Start of Protests as Crisis Eases |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>
===7 February=== {{multiple image | width1 = 150 | width2 = 180 | align = | footer = From left to right: An [[Imam (Sunni Islam)|imam]] of [[Al-Azhar University]], who was wounded in his eye during the protests and An anti-government protester in Tahrir Square. The placard reads "''Leave leave and rest assured, the chaos will leave with you, leave leave.''". | image1 = Azharite in Tahrir.jpg | image2 = Protester on pavement in Tahrir.jpg }} Hundreds of thousands of protesters camped out in Tahrir Square where a symbolic funeral procession was held for Ahmed Mahmoud. Protesters demanded that an investigation be carried out into the cause of his death.<ref>{{cite web|author=Laila Al-Arian |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/indepth/spotlight/anger-in-egypt/2011/02/201126201341479784.html |title=Killed in the line of duty â Anger in Egypt |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
At least 70 people were wounded when hundreds of residents attacked the police station in Khargah to demand the ouster of a police official who had a reputation for heavy-handedness. Police then opened fire on the protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110208/D9L8NDD03.html |title=Freed young leader energizes Egyptian protests |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> Authorities said that 11 people had been killed.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/06/live-blog-feb-7-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 7 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> The United Nations estimated deaths at more than 300.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/02/08/egypt-documented-death-toll-protests-tops-300 |title=Egypt: Documented Death Toll From Protests Tops 300 | Human Rights Watch |publisher=Hrw.org |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
Finance Minister Samir Radwan announced a 15 per cent raise in pensions and salaries for government employees at a cost of 6.5 billion [[Egyptian pounds]] (US$960 million). This decision was made at the first Cabinet meeting since the protests began. One protester said that protests would not end soon because of the regime's increasing concessions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110207/D9L7VGTG1.html |title=Egypt approves 15 percent raise for govt employees |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> While banks had reopened, schools and the stock exchange remained closed. The [[Egyptian Exchange|Egyptian Stock Exchange]] said it would resume operation on 13 February.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb" /> Minister of Antiquities Zahi Hawass announced that artifacts damaged by looters would be restored over the next five days. He said that steps were being taken to reopen Egypt's famed archaeological sites, which had been closed since pro-democracy protests started. Among the damaged objects was a statue of [[King Tutankhamun]] standing on a panther and a wooden [[sarcophagus]] from the [[New Kingdom]] period, dating to roughly 3,500 years ago. The museum, which is adjacent to the anti-government protests in downtown Cairo, was being guarded by the army.<ref name="aljazbloglive7feb" /> Former minister of the interior [[Habib Ibrahim El Adly|Habib El-Adli]] faced prosecution in a military court for ordering police to fire at protesters and for<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/07/us-egypt-adli-idUSTRE7163D420110207 |title=Egypt's ex-police chief appears before prosecutors |publisher=Reuters |date= 7 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-08 |first=Andrew |last=Hammond}}</ref> his role in the 31 December 2010 bombing of al-Qiddissin Church in Alexandria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ikhwanweb.com/article.php?id=27982|title=Former Interior Minister Habib El Adly Accused of Being Involved in Alex Qiddisin's Church Bombings|publisher=Ikhwan Web|date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref>
State-owned ''[[Al-Ahram]]'', declared its support for the protesters and stopped supporting the regime.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8309469/Egypt-crisis-Hosni-Mubarak-loses-control-of-state-media.html |title=Egypt crisis: Hosni Mubarak loses control of state media |publisher=Telegraph |date= 7 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-08 |location=London |first=Adrian |last=Blomfield}}</ref>
[[Wael Ghonim]], [[Google]]'s head of Marketing for the Middle East and North Africa and the founder of the Facebook page that was said to have been influential in fomenting the protests, who had been in custody since 25 January, was reported to have been released.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/06/live-blog-feb-7-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 7 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://twitter.com/#!/google/status/34676106900541440 |title=Huge relief--Wael Ghonim has been released. Our love to him and his family. |author=Google |publisher=Twitter |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> At 20:00, he posted on ''Twitter'' that "Freedom is a blessing that deserves fighting for it." (''sic'')<ref>{{cite web |url=http://twitter.com/#!/Ghonim/status/34673818375032832 |title=Freedom is a blessing that deserves fighting for it. |last=Ghonim |first=Wael |publisher=Twitter |date=7 February 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> His release from custody and an emotional interview with [[Mona El-Shazly]] on DreamTV<ref>{{citation|last=Mackey|first=Robert|date=2011/02/08|title=Subtitled Video of Wael Ghonimâs Emotional TV Interview|url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/08/subtitled-video-of-wael-ghonims-emotional-tv-interview/|work=The New York Times}}</ref> have been instrumental in warming up the mobiliation,<ref>{{cite news|last=Fahim|first=Kareem|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/09/world/middleeast/09ghonim.html?_r=2&scp=1&sq=Mona_El-Nagger&st=cse|title=Emotions of a Reluctant Hero Galvanize Protesters|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=2011-03-05|date=8 February 2011}}</ref> encouraged thousands of supporters to join a Facebook page created in his honour. "We authorise Wael Ghoneim to speak on behalf of the Egyptian revolution."<ref name="aljazeera3">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/07/live-blog-feb-8-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 8 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}} [http://www.facebook.com/Authorize.Ghoneim?v=info Link to Facebook page in Arabic from blogpost.] Retrieved 2011-02-14.</ref> He issued a statement reading: <blockquote>First of all my sincere condolences for all the Egyptians that lost their lives. I am really sorry for their loss, none of us wanted this. We were not destroying things. We all wanted peaceful protests, and our slogan was ''no to vandalism''. Please don't turn me into a hero. I am not a hero, I am someone that was asleep for 12 days. The real heroes are the ones that took to the streets, please focus your cameras on the right people. I am ok. (''sic'') God willing we will change our country, and all the filth that was taking place in the country has to stop. Together we will clean this country. â Wael Ghonim<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/08/timeline-how-wael-ghonim-became-one-of-the-faces-of-egypts-uprising/ |title=Timeline: How Wael Ghonim became one of the faces of Egyptâs uprising | Posted | National Post |publisher=News.nationalpost.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref></blockquote>
===8 February â Day of Egypt's Love=== [[File:Tahrir Square during 8 February 2011.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the "Day of Egypt's Love"]] The earlier organizers called for a new protest in what was dubbed the "'''Day of Egypt's Love'''". ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙ Ø­Ø¨ Ù ØµØ±}}).<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/789346B3-1C7E-408F-8F8B-13A8207298C5.htm?wbc_purpose=Basic%2CBasic_Current|title=Ù Ø¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ù ÙÙÙÙÙØ© Ø¨Ù ØµØ± ØªØµØ¹ÙØ¯ Ø§ÙØ¶ØºØ·|publisher=Aljazeera|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
Over a million people gathered in and around Tahrir Square to demonstrate.<ref name="aljazeera3" /> At least 1,000 went to the [[Egyptian Parliament|parliament]] to demand Mubarak's resignation while others went to the ''Shura Council'' and the ''Council of Ministers''. They later slept in front of those buildings, besides the usual camp in Tahrir Square.
A substantial protest took place in Alexandria,<ref name="aljazbloglive8feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/07/live-blog-feb-8-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 8 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> while workers at the Suez Canal went on strike.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5231/Egypt/Politics-/Suez-Canal-workers-go-on-strike-.aspx |title=Five Suez Canal companies workers go on strike, no major disruptions witnessed yet - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> BBC correspondents reported that by the afternoon the protests had the highest turnout to date.<ref>{{cite news|author=Yolande Knell |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12394941 |title=BBC News - Egypt protests: Hosni Mubarak's concessions rejected |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= 8 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
Hundreds of journalists gathered in the lobby of the state-owned newspaper ''[[Al-Ahram]]''<nowiki>'</nowiki>s headquarters to protest corruption and to call for greater freedom of the press.<ref name="NYT Strike">{{cite news|journal=New York Times|title=Protest in Egypt Takes a Turn as Workers Go on Strike|date=February 9|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/10/world/middleeast/10egypt.html|accessdate=February 9, 2011|first1=Kareem|last1=Fahim|first2=David D.|last2=Kirkpatrick}}</ref>
In a statement on Egyptian state television, Suleiman announced the formation of two independent committees for political and constitutional reforms, both starting work immediately. One committee would carry out constitutional and legislative amendments to enable a shift of power. The other would monitor the implementation of all proposed reforms. Suleiman also stressed that demonstrators would not be prosecuted and that a separate independent fact-finding committee would be established to probe the violence of 2 February.<ref name="aljazeera4">{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201128123235508653.html |title=Protests swell at Tahrir Square |publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |date= 8 February 2011 |accessdate= 8 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/02/massive-demonstrations-in-cairo-draw-thousands.html|title=Egypt's Military Leaders Dissolve Parliament, Suspend Constitution, New Strikes Begin |publisher=PBS |date=|accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> He said that wider press freedoms were under consideration and that he would produce a list of what was needed to hold free elections.<ref>{{cite web|last=Namatalla |first=Ahmed A |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-08/suleiman-to-meet-media-chiefs-in-bid-to-show-egypt-moving-on-press-freedom.html |title=Egyptians Rally in Cairo as Suleiman Pledges Change |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref> He also said that plans were underway to organize a peaceful transfer of power.<ref name="aljazbloglive8feb" /> Suleiman reiterated his view that Egypt was not ready for democracy, while warning of a possible [[coup d'Ã©tat]] unless demonstrators agreed to enter negotiations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110209/D9L9A7UO0.html |title=Egypt protesters defy VP warnings they must stop |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref>
Ibrahim Yosri, a lawyer and former deputy foreign minister, drafted a petition, along with 20 other lawyers, asking the Prosecutor General Abdel Meguid Mahmoud to try Mubarak and his family for stealing state wealth.<ref name="aljazeera4" />
According to the state-owned Middle East News Agency, Interior Minister [[Mahmoud Wagdy]] issued an order releasing 34 political detainees, mostly members of the Muslim Brotherhood.<ref name="aljazprison">{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201128153142101446.html |title=Egypt 'frees political prisoners' |publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |date= 8 February 2011 |accessdate= 8 February 2011}}</ref>
===9 February=== {{multiple image | width1 = 250 | width2 = 175 | align = | footer = From left to right: Tahrir Square during the evening of 9 February and a sign on the Parliament building in Cairo on 9 February, reading "Closed until the fall of the regime". | image1 = Tahrir Square - February 9, 2011.png | image2 = The Egyptian parliament building during 9 February (Closed).jpg }} Some protesters moved from Tahrir Square to the area outside the parliament buildings, while demanding the assembly's immediate dissolution. The demonstrators put up a sign that said: "Closed until the fall of the regime". Cabinet offices in Cairo were evacuated after anti-government protesters gathered outside the building. Meanwhile, labour unions across the country, and particularly in Alexandria, Cairo and Suez, staged [[general strike]]s, demanding higher wages and better treatment. The strikers were said to number around 20,000 workers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112913546831171.html |title=Workers boost Egypt protests - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Violent clashes were reported in [[Wadi al-Jadid]], where police stations and the NDP party building were destroyed, and several deaths and hundreds of injuries also occurred.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/08/live-blog-feb-9-egypt-protests |title=Live blog Feb 9 - Egypt protests | Al Jazeera Blogs |publisher=Blogs.aljazeera.net |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> Protesters in [[Port Said]] burnt down the governor's office in response to his reluctance to provide enough housing for the city's residents.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/314229 |title=Residents set Port Said Governorate HQ alight | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Clashes were said to have killed three people and wounded hundreds more in the past two days.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201129181744289932.html "Egyptians mourn uprising dead"] ''Aljazeera'' - Retrieved 9 February 2011.</ref><!--need to add to casualty table-->
Egyptians living outside the country returned to join the anti-government demonstrations. An Internet campaign sought to mobilise thousands of expatriates to return home and support the uprising.<ref name="Jazeera Feb9">{{cite web |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201129103224329921.html |title=Egypt protesters gain ground |author= |date=9 February 2011 |publisher=[[Al-Jazeera English]] |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref>
The government followed up on a prisoner amnesty from the previous day, releasing 1,000 more prisoners who had served three-quarters of their sentence; 840 more were released from [[Sinai Peninsula|Sinai province]].<ref name="aljazprison" /> The [[Muslim Brotherhood]] continued to demand for Mubarak's resignation.<ref name="aljazbloglive9feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/08/live-blog-feb-9-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 9 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> The offices of state-owned Channel 5 in Alexandria were shut down and evacuated under the order of its chief amid mounting pressure by protesters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5311/Egypt/Politics-/Egypts-Channel--broadcast-cut-as-army-surrounds-HQ.aspx |title=Egypt's Channel 5 broadcast cut as army surrounds HQ - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> The government warned of a military crackdown amid ongoing protests.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.khaleejtimes.com/DisplayArticle09.asp?xfile=data/middleeast/2011/February/middleeast_February275.xml&section=middleeast |title=Egypt regime warns of crackdown as revolt spreads |publisher=Khaleejtimes.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-09}}</ref> Foreign Minister [[Ahmed Aboul Gheit]] rejected US calls to repeal the emergency law and also accused the US of trying to impose its will on the Egyptian government.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112919546727393.html |title=Egypt rejects US advice on reforms - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Culture Minister [[Gaber Asfour]] resigned after one week in office, citing health problems.<ref>{{cite news|last=Weaver |first=Matthew |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/09/egypt-protests-live-updates-9-february |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 9 February | News | guardian.co.uk |publisher=Guardian |date= 9 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-09 |location=London}}</ref>
===10 February=== [[File:Tahrir Square - February 10, 2011.png|thumb|Over 2 millions protesting in [[Tahrir Square]] on February 10, 2011 after [[Hosni Mubarak]]'s speech saying that they'll go to his palace the day after.]] The protests continued at Tahrir Square and the parliament building. 3,000 lawyers marched from the lawyers' syndicate in downtown Cairo to [[Abdeen Palace]], one of Mubarak's official residences. About a thousand physicians, dressed in white coats, also arrived at Tahrir Square to applause.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/09/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> Strikes at national industries, including tourism and transportation, continued and spread to Alexandria, Mahalla and Port Said.<ref name="VOA-20110210">{{cite news|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Protests-Strikes-Spread-as-Egypts-Regime-Stiffens-115706904.html|title=Protests, Strikes Spread as Egypt's Regime Stiffens|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|date=February 10, 2011|accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> Protesters around Egypt, expecting Mubarak's resignation, were described as euphoric, while singing and waving Egyptian flags.<ref>{{cite web|author=By Sarah El Deeb |url=http://www.buffalonews.com/wire-feeds/24-hour-world-news/article338025.ece |title=Expecting Mubarak to go, protest camp euphoric - 24 Hour World News |publisher=The Buffalo News |date=2011-02-10 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref> Fighter aircraft were heard above the Tahrir Square at 20:00 amid calls for the "destruction of the regime." In Alexandria, over 1,000 "diehard" protesters were reported by the train station.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-10-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 10 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>
Prior to Mubarak's speech, contradictory reports from various media sources around the world stated that either Suleiman or Tantawi was expected to take over.<ref>[http://www.globes.co.il/news/article.aspx?did=1000622357 ××¦×¨×× ×××¨× ×××©××¨ ×¦×××? ×××××¨×§ ×¦×¤×× ×××ª×¤××¨ ××¢×¨×], Israel's [[Globes]] newspaper, 2 February 2011</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Fam |first=Mariam |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-may-resign-before-september-egyptian-ruling-party-official-says.html |title=Egypt's President Mubarak May Step Down as Army Meets |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> The military council also met without Mubarak.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> The Muslim Brotherhood had feared a coup at one point. The head of the NDP said that Mubarak should go for the good of the country.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" />
[[Al Hurra]] TV reported that Mubarak was planning to hand authority to the Egyptian army.<ref>{{he}}[[Ehud Yaari]], [[Israeli News Company]], [[Channel 2 (Israel)]] [http://www.mako.co.il/news-world/arab/Article-a084cdc90101e21004.htm ×××××¨×§ ××¢×××¨ ××ª ×¡××××××ª×× ××¦××]</ref> General Hassan al-Roueini, the military commander for the Cairo area, told protesters in Tahrir Square, "All your demands will be met today."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA0CHO0.html |title=Military says Mubarak will meet protesters demands |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> State TV added that Mubarak would speak that night from his Cairo palace. This came after Egypt's military proclaimed on television that they had stepped in to "safeguard the country". The ''Associated Press'' suggested a military coup might be occurring. State TV showed Defence Minister [[Field Marshal]] Mohamed Hussein Tantawi meeting with two dozen top army officers. Mubarak and Suleiman were not present.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA1S980.html |title=Mubarak meets with VP, protesters flood square |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
{{quotebox|"...I thought I would delegate powers to the vice president, according to the constitution..."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="Mubarak's stepping down speech">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/10/egypt.mubarak.statement/ |title=Full text of Mubarak's speech |work=[[CNN]]|date=10 February 2011|accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
However, information minister Anas el-Fiqqi, denied that Mubarak would resign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2IBO0.html |title=Egyptian minister denies Mubarak will step down |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Prime Minister [[Ahmed Shafiq]] said, "everything is in the hands of President Hosni Mubarak and no decisions have been taken yet."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA2SHO3.html |title=Egypt army takes charge, Mubarak to address nation |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> Al Arabiya television, citing "trusted sources" just minutes before Mubarak was to speak, said he would transfer his powers to his vice president.<ref>{{cite news|last=Blair |first=Edmund |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/10/us-egypt-idUSTRE70O3UW20110210 |title=Mubarak to announce handover in speech: TV |publisher=Reuters.com |date= 10 February 2011|accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref>
In his television statement, Mubarak said that he would penalise those responsible for the violence and had a clear vision on how to end the crisis, but was satisfied with what he had offered. He stated that while remaining president to the end of his term in September he would transfer his powers to the vice-president.<ref>{{cite web|last=Shahine |first=Alaa |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-10/mubarak-ignores-calls-for-ouster-delegates-authority-to-egypt-s-suleiman.html |title=Mubarak Defiance of Ouster Calls Angers Protesters |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref><ref name=transfers/> As far as transfer of power was concerned, Mubarak said "I have seen that it is required to delegate the powers and authorities of the president to the vice president as dictated in the constitution,". The constitutional article was used to transfer powers if the president was "temporarily" unable to carry out his duties and did not require his resignation.<ref name=transfers/> He also said he would request six constitutional amendments and that he would lift emergency laws when security in the country permitted.<ref name=transfers/> Mubarak said he would stay in the country and was "adamant to continue to shoulder my responsibility to protect the constitution and safeguard the interests of the people ... until power is handed over to those elected in September by the people in free and fair elections in which all the guarantees of transparencies will be secured."<ref name=transfers/>
Protesters watched in stunned silence or in anger to his speech, some crying or waving their shoes in the air.<ref name=transfers/> People in Tahrir Square chanted "Leave! Leave! Leave!" after Mubarak's speech.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://parkerspitzer.blogs.cnn.com/2011/02/10/mubarak-says-hes-staying-until-september/ |title=Mubarak says he's staying until September |publisher=Parker Spitzer - CNN.com Blogs |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Suleiman called on the protesters to go home.<ref name=transfers>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA5RQO0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak transfers power to vice president |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Protesters then moved to the state television and radio buildings.<ref name="aljazbloglive10feb" /> Soon after the television announcement, a large number of protesters began to march towards the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|author=By: Report | February 11, 2011 | 0 views | No Comments |url=http://www.vindianz.com/business/oil-gains-stocks-euro-fall-mostly-calm-on-egypt-news-wall-street-journal-041301.html |title=Oil Gains; Stocks, Euro Fall; Mostly Calm On Egypt News â Wall Street Journal |publisher=vIndianz.com |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref> ElBaradei said, "Egypt will explode" because Mubarak refused to step down and called on the military to intervene.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110210/D9LA71380.html |title=ElBaradei calls on Egyptian army to intervene |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
Mubarak's top aides, family and son Gamal told him he could ride out the turmoil, which convinced him to cling to power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110212/D9LBGH2O0.html |title=Mubarak's final hours: Desperate bids to stay |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-13}}</ref> It was also reported that one son, Alaa, accused his younger brother Gamal of ruining their father's reputation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Sabel |first=Robbie |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=208106 |title='Mubarak's sons nearly come to blows during speech' |publisher=Jpost.com |date=2011-02-14 |accessdate=2011-02-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/13/us-egypt-mubarak-sons-idUSTRE71C26L20110213 |title=Sons of Egypt's Mubarak nearly came to blows: report |publisher= |date= 13 February 2011|accessdate=2011-04-08 |work=Reuters |first=Andrew |last=Hammond}}. Reuters. Retrieved on 2011-04-08.</ref> Eyewitnesses said that the Egyptian army had pulled out troops from many locations near the presidential palace.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/315254 |title=Witnesses: Egyptian army withdraws from positions near presidential palace |publisher=Almasryalyoum.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
===11 February=== [[File:Celebratory protesters.jpg|thumb|Egyptians in Giza celebrate Mubarak's resignation.]] [[File:Protesters with soldier.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A soldier joins the protesters in celebration of Mubarak's downfall.]] Shock that Mubarak did not step down resulted in a nationwide escalation of protests on 11 February, named again as the '''"Friday of Departure"''' by the opposition movement.<ref name="signonsandiego1">{{cite news | last = Schemm | first = Paul | last2 = Michael | first2 = Maggie | agency = Associated Press | date = 2011-02-05 | url = http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/2011/feb/11/mubarak-leaves-cairo-for-sinai-as-protests-spread/ | title = Mubarak leaves Cairo for Sinai as protests spread | publisher = SignOnSanDiego.com | accessdate = 2011-02-12 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|publisher=Al Jazeera|title=Egypt's army vows smooth transition|date=February 12, 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121217639448807.html|accessdate=February 13, 2011}}</ref> Massive protests continued in Cairo, Alexandria, and other cities. The presidential palace and parliament remained surrounded by protestors and thousands of people surrounded the state TV building, keeping anyone from entering or leaving. The army issued a ''[[communiquÃ©]]'' supporting Mubarak's attempt to remain ''[[de jure]]'' president.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egyptian army backs Hosni Mubarak and calls for protesters to go home|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/11/egyptian-army-backs-hosni-mubarak|first=Paul|last=Owen|date=2011/02/11|publisher=Guardian.co.uk|location=London}}</ref> Hossam Badrawi, the new secretary of the NDP, resigned from unhappiness with Mubarak's refusal to leave.<ref>[http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/02/11/latest-updates-on-day-18-of-egypt-protests/?hp "Latest Updates on Day 18 of Egypt Protests"] by Robert Mackey - ''The New York Times.'.' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref>
Demonstrators began to gather at new locations in Cairo. The army surrounded the presidential palace and state television and radio buildings<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/10/live-blog-feb-11-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 11 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=11 February 2011}}</ref> as protesters surrounded the Egyptian radio and television union building demanding fair media coverage. State television shifted its attitude towards the protesters and begun referring to them as Jan25 Youth Revolution<!-- is this precise? -->, admitting mistakes had been made in the media coverage of the protests: "We [the state TV] were under an information chaos," the news anchor stated. "We had strict orders from external sides."<ref>{{cite web|author=Lindsay Carroll|url=http://www.demotiximages.com/news/587341/egypts-joy-after-mubaraks-step-down |title=Egypt's Joy after Mubarak's Step Down | Demotix.com |publisher=Demotiximages.com |date= |accessdate=2011-03-05}}</ref> Major protests occurred in Alexandria and Mansoura. In [[Arish]], in north Sinai, the second police station in 24 hours came under heavy arms fireâincluding RPGsâin which at least one protester<!-- need to add to total tally --> was killed and 20 injured, with possibly more police fatalities.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" />
==== Resignation ====
As the protesters started marching onto the Presidential Palace in the morning, Mubarak and his family reportedly left the Palace by helicopter which took them to the nearby Almaza Airbase, why they boarded the Presidential jet and headed to [[Sharm el-Sheikh]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAK12O0.html |title=Egypt's Mubarak in Red Sea resort as protests rage |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Former Finance Minister [[Youssef Boutros Ghali]] fled to [[Beirut]].<ref name="ahram1">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/5408/Egypt/Politics-/Youssef-Boutros-Ghali-leaves-Egypt.aspx |title=Youssef Boutros Ghali leaves Egypt - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>
{{Rquote|right|In the name of God the merciful, the compassionate, citizens, during these very difficult circumstances Egypt is going through, President Hosni Mubarak has decided to step down from the office of president of the republic and has charged the high council of the armed forces to administer the affairs of the country. May God help everybody.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mondoweiss.net/2011/02/mubarak-resigns-and-hands-power-to-military-as-egyptians-hit-the-streets-on-farewell-friday.html |title=Mubarak is out! Hands power to military as Egyptians hit the streets on âFarewell Fridayâ |publisher=Mondoweiss.net |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref>|[[Omar Suleiman]], Vice President of the Arab Republic of Egypt}}
{{Rquote|right|The people of Egypt have spoken, their voices have been heard, and Egypt will never be the same.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Obama: Egypt Will Never Be The Same|last=Klein|first=Kent|publisher=''Voanews.com''|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/Obama-Egypt-Will-Never-Be-the-Same-115965119.html|date=11/2/11|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref>|[[Barack Obama]], United States president}}
Vice President Omar Suleiman announced after 18:00 Cairo local time (GMT +2) on 11 February that the presidency had been vacated and the army council would run the country:<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Mubarak's resignation was followed by nationwide celebrations.<ref name="ahram1"/> ElBaradei told the ''Associated Press'' "This is the greatest day of my life. The country has been liberated after decades of repression," and he expected a "beautiful" transition of power.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110211/D9LAM4LO0.html |title=Mubarak resigns, hands power to military |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei said that "Egypt is free."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monstersandcritics.com/news/middleeast/news/article_1618774.php/ElBaradei-Egypt-is-a-free-and-proud-nation-Extra |title=ElBaradei: Egypt is a free and proud nation (Extra) |publisher=Monsters and Critics |date=2010-11-17 |accessdate=2011-02-14}}</ref> Various media outlets pointed out that this date was also the anniversary of the Iranian [[Islamic Revolution]], which occurred on 11 February 1979.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sify.com/news/iran-congratulates-egyptian-people-s-victory-news-international-lcmcacigiid.html |title=Iran congratulates Egyptian people's 'victory' |publisher=Sify.com |date= |accessdate=2011-02-12}}</ref>
An [[exchange traded fund]] based on the Egyptian stock market listed at the [[NYSE Euronext]] increased by 5% following the announcement. Egyptian five-year [[credit default swaps]] fell by 0.25%. ''Al Arabiya'' reported that the military council said it would sack the cabinet and dissolve parliament, although they only did the latter.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebrations and car honking were reported in Alexandria and Cairo.<ref name="aljazbloglive11feb" /> Celebratory gunfire in Gaza.<ref>{{cite web|author=Font size Print E-mail Share |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/12/ap/world/main7342637.shtml |title=Mubarak Exit Sets Off Celebrations Across Mideast |publisher=CBS News |date=2011-02-11 |accessdate=2011-06-05}}</ref>
[[CBS]] correspondent [[Lara Logan]] was covering the jubilation in Tahrir Square when she suffered a brutal and sustained sexual assault and beating before being saved by a group of women and an estimated 20 Egyptian soldiers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1357485/Lara-Logan-assault-Former-GMTV-reporter-suffers-sex-attack-covering-Egypt-uprising.html |title=Ex-GMTV reporter Lara Logan leaves hospital six days after Cairo mob sex-attack - and vows to be back at work within weeks |publisher=Dailymail.co.uk |date=2011-02-16 |accessdate=2011-02-20 |location=London}}</ref> {{-}}
